results.title: Eternal France
results.creator_credit: August von Kageneck, James R. Conner and Kageneck Video
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Video visits”.
From the Roman ruins in Provence to Napoleon’s Arc de Triomphe in Paris, the rich history and culture of France awaits you. Wander inside the majestic Cathedrals of Reims and Chartres. Watch the artistry of glass-makers in Baccarat, the lacemakers in the Auvergne and silk painters in Lyon. Then, marvel at the beauty and mystery of Brittany’s stunning abbey of Mont-Saint-Michel.
results.creator_credit_for_label: August von Kageneck, James R. Conner and Kageneck Video

results.title: Eternal children
results.creator_credit: Don Haldane, David Bairstow and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Children who through heredity, brain injury or various other causes are not equipped to keep pace in a competitive world - are they to be society’s unwitting castaways? This film gives a frank appraisal of the problem and shows methods of care and training being developed in special schools and institutions for the mentally disabled. (Awards: Columbus; New York)

results.title: Eternal change: story of a mountain
results.brief_description: Traces the origin of Mount Rainier from eruption through a rift in the surface and its development in subsequent volcanic action. Shows the cycle of the seasons, the erosion by wind and water, the action of snow and ice and the movement of the glaciers.

results.title: Et la Terre Fut ...
results.brief_description:
Episode 1 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
This first episode deals with the formation of the Earth and the apparition of life on Earth with the amphibians and other prehistorical animals. This episode also covers the evolution of primates, the domestication of fire and the development of hunting techniques.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: Et cetera. Season 2. Episode 7 [The State Library. Melbourne Cup handover. Tumbarumba]
results.brief_description:
Northern Access Television produced this episode of the
series “Et cetera” featuring a visit to the State Library of
Victoria and an interview with Melinda Dundas - Public
Affairs Officer, who talks of the services available to
residents and tourists, and multicultural, regional and youth oriented initiatives. Interviewer Suzana Talevski
also speaks to Librarian Des Cawley. Justine Isard reports
from the Windsor Hotel where the handover of the Melbourne Cup by the Hardy Brothers to the Victorian Racing Club (VRC) is taking place. Includes footage of the cup’s production. Phillip Taylor speaks to percussion group
Tumbarumba. Presented by David McLauchlan.

results.title: Et cetera. Episode 7 [The Big issue. International Women's day]
results.creator_credit: Northern Access TV, Michael Costello and David McLauchlan
results.brief_description: Et cetera “The Big Issue and International Woman’s Day” is an episode of the general interest magazine program “Et Cetera”. It contains two topics - the first is about the alternative magazine sold on the streets by homeless and unemployed people “The Big Issue”. The second is a look at the celebration of International Woman’s Day, which featrued a rally and march down Swanston Street in Melbourne.

results.title: Et cetera. Episode 6 [Joe Felber Multimedia Installation]
results.creator_credit: Northern Access TV, Michael Costello and David McLauchlan
results.brief_description: Presented by David McLauchlan outside the Australian Centre for Contemporary Art, Melbourne. David interviews multimedia artist Joe Felber and dancer/choreographer Lucy Guerin about their collaborative installation with composer Elliott Gyger entitled “25 songs on 25 lines of 25 words on Art Statement for seven voices and dance” based on Ad Reinhardt’s Black Painting and Art Statement. Following the interviews, there is a presentation of Joe Felber’s 7 minute video on the multimedia performance “25 songs on 25 lines…and dance”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Northern Access TV, Michael Costello and David McLauchlan

results.title: Et cetera. Episode 3 [1999 Melbourne Fringe Festival]
results.creator_credit: Northern Access TV, Michael Costello and David McLauchlan
results.brief_description:
Documents the 1999 Melbourne Fringe Festival Parade and the Fringe Furniture Exhibition, including interviews with Virginia Hyam, Fringe Director, and Axel, Fringe Furniture Co-ordinator. The Melbourne Fringe Festival has become an institution since its inception in 1982 when a small group of independent artists gathered together to create a platform to present new and independent art to the community. From those early beginnings the Melbourne-based festival now attracts interstate and international guests and covers a wide variety of arts
performances including outdoor events such as the Annual Parade in Brunswick Street, Fitzroy, the Annual Waiter’s Race, street-theatre and live bands and indoor events including comedy and cabaret, music and theatre. The Fringe Furniture Exhibition allows for young students
and designers an opportunity to show-off their creative ability and caters for non-mainstream pieces. Crazy, outrageous, quirky and even occasionally practical, the Exhibition contains an amazing selection of eclectic pieces as witnessed in this documentary program.
Reporters: Melissa Iaria and Phillip Taylor.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Northern Access TV, Michael Costello and David McLauchlan
